Participant2 you mean that school is not for african people?
I mean that "ENCOURAGE FEWER PEOPLE TO GO TO UNIVERSITY" sounds like that, it sounds like discrimination.

I think that recruiters look for engineering students because they may learn something practical and usefull in daily life in a firm. It seems that lessons in the university are more about theorical or about research isn't it ?
For instance, it happens that students are forcing themselves through university even when it is not right for them.
Besides i think that university must be open to people because it gives the chance for a larger number of people to go back for studying in order to get a licence at least.
Participant3: Sure, but if we compute the years that you spend to accomplish you Phd degree vs. the time you spend to find a job, so I guess, it is not so interesting to do it.
Participant2: yes you should find the one or the things to encourage you.
Sometimes, you choose the domain of your PhD just because you have found some findings (Scholarships) with this domain, and not because you LIKE it.
PhD is maybe more about a work on research in the subject you have chosen.
Or you find an advisor ready to guide you.
People should be encouraged to learn new things, in early childhood then in the school, then college, and as the highest step in the university.
It depends on how many years you spend to do Phd for example.
Participant3: but research is also a well paid job :)

In conclusion, I think that people should be aware of the consequence of going to university (time, money, stress...). But if they are convinced that they are doing a good job and especially that they like the domain on which they are working, so I encourage them to do it :)
To finish, people should go to universities, but they should be convinced and encouraged in the field they choose.
Students must alternate with something practical and lessons at the university in order to ensure their competences as their knowledge.
